Posted: February 2, 2014
												Despite already owning a copy for the Xbox 360, I do not regret purchasing this game on Steam as well. As it would turn out, when DICE isn't busy in an uphill battle with Call of Duty, they have the ability to churn out works of art like this one.The storyline of this game is one that I met with a resounding 'eh'. Despite having a brilliant setup with many different directions to go in, it goes for the more subtle route based on what the main character, Faith finds most important. I wont spoil it too much, but I will say that your character, in this game at least isn't going to be playing the great big hero. But also not an antihero. Her job of transporting sensitive information as discreetly as possible is iffy at best, but at her core she clearly cares about others, even more than herself. I'd like to see Mirror's Edge 2 explore the more story driven aspect, but Mirrors' Edge's story is just alright.But everything else about this game feels like gold. Between the beautiful visuals which shine through even on lower end hardware, the amazing(if occasionally redundant) musical score, and the phoenominal gameplay, you not only get a stunning experience, but a deeply emotional one, too, and not in terms of a storyline. When I hop in an elevator and rapidly click the up button while bullet holes spur up in the door after being chased by 20 cops, I let out the same breath of fresh air Faith does. And when Faith takes a plunge to her death during a particularly adrenaline pumping chase sequence, I almost feel like I'm going to actually die.This whole package is wrapped up in a fantastically optimized piece of software. I own a low end machine, and the framerate ranges from dreamlike to slightly choppy, but it never becomes unplayable or difficult to control, even on an entry level laptop. And I can only imagine what it must be like to play on a higher end piece of hardware.The way the game works with a controller is, while unconventional, very smooth and well put together, but the keyboard and mouse is where it's at with this title. I'll spare the details, but all I can say is that you don't know good control until you've touched a DICE game.Another largely refreshing aspect is the gunplay. Traditional aim assisting mechanics have been foregone for a greater sense of realism. It not only feels refreshing to have gunplay be more skill based than about getting your crosshairs relatively near the target, but it also provides an incentive for you to drop your weapons periodically. With no reloads or tons of ammo, and most weapons weighing you down from sprinting or doing the parkour moves this game is great for, it provides the player a reason to not just lug around a big weapon all the time.The game's biggest drawback however is the production value. It certainly did get a solid budget being a AAA release, but some... interesting design decisions were made in lieu of a larger budget. The Flash animated cutscenes are some of the best Flash animations I've seen in a LONG time, but they feel somewhat out of place with the rest of the game's style. Not to mention the clunkiness behind grabbing your opponents' gun could really be worked on. Last but not least, the game was short for what it was. The campaign is only a few hours long, and with no multiplayer to pad it out(unless you like time trials) and a lack of mod support, you'll be left hungry for more. And even with how few levels there are, some of them are fairly boring, such as generic boat, generic high security building, and not to mention, generic subway station. However, all of these are refreshed a bit with the art style being so fantastic, but at the end of the day I would've liked to see more creative ventures like you in The Shard or New Eden Mall.No matter the production value, however, this game is well worth the $20 price, and an absolute must have if you ever see it on sale. You probably wont need to worry too much about if your computer can run it decently, so long as you have at least a 2.6 GhZ CPU(counting cores) and a half decent graphics card. Mirror's Edge is an experience that I think everyone should have.

												I honestly don't know where to begin, other than saying that this is a great game. And I truely mean it. With a compelling story, fascinating and yet unique gameplay, and georgeous level design, this game forms a true masterpiece.While the story certainly isn't  BioShock-level great (no, I'm not comparing this game to BioShock), it's not bad either. You play as a runner (the "protagonists" of the story), Faith, and save her sister after she's been accused of murder. Nothing to fancy. Unless you've complete the game, however, but I'm not going to spoil it. The story also is a bit short, I managed to complete it in 4 and a half hours, and that was on my first run through it. Story - 7/10The graphics some will say aren't the best, and I can see that. But I think that the game looks spectacular when running at the highest settings. Brilliant use of color, especially an uncommonly used color in games these days, white. The lighting helps too, however, it proved to be a bit annoying in some levels, but that's okay as you can turn the brightness down if you wish. The levels mainly consist of rooftops, and sometimes inside a building. However, you will also explore the inside of a storm drain, alleyways, and a harbor. I did think that it was a bit linear - at first it seems like pathways branch, and they do, but only in certain segments of a level. (Example, you're on a rooftop, and there is a gate. There are multiple ways to get around the gate, but once you do get around it, lies behind it a ramp you're to spring off of.)  Level deisgn/graphics - 8/10While the gameplay may look quirky in videos, and actually may seem quirky when learning them for the first time, believe me, they're not. You'll get used to them right away, and just like the game's purpose, you'll flow smoothly right through the stages. The game isn't that difficult, but some levels can be. You also can use guns, which was actually going to be a bigger element of gameplay in earlier versions, it really isn't that big. They work like normal guns, should - they shoot.  But honestly, they didn't feel needed, if it weren't for how many cops the game throws at you in certain levels. But like I said before, the game's intenion is to flow through the levels. They want the gameplay to become a natural thing. And I think they achieved that.Gameplay - 9/10Mirror's Edge is a wonderful, exhilerating action-platformer that requires some skill. While things may look different through a video, the game will suck you in and drop you into a whole new world of flow and colors. I think it is completely worth the $20 it charges, though if a sale is coming quite soon, I reccomend waiting as you won't be missing much. Final verdict - 8/10

												A beautiful game with a very distinct art style. While in the actual game you're in a 3D environment, the story parts are in 2D, in style reminiscent of a graphic novel.Gameplay can become quite frustrating at times, as timing is extremely important. You might find youself repeating the same part of the level literally dozens of times. After the first three levels though, you should probably understand how to solve most of the problems.The tutorial, while going very in-depth and showing you practically every move you might need in-game, feeds you all the information in one five-minute session. If you're not one of those people that remember every combination of keystrokes right away, you might find yourself in a pinch not knowing what to do when faced with certain obstacles (going from personal experience: by forgetting I had the ability to double tap space while wall running, I added probably one or two hours of gameplay and frustration to my first playthrough). But once you get the hang of the controls and figure out the different ways you can use your surroundings to move around, most of the levels become a breeze.While the story, in terms of development, is pretty predictable, there's a few aspects that make it (and the whole game) stand out. For one, the main character is a woman of Asian descent, who instead of being driven by some kind of romantic nonsense, is trying to save her sister. No one makes a deal about her being a woman, no one even acknowledges it. She's not special because of it. She's just another runner. And that is really great, in my opinion.In conclussion: after two hours of head-bashing against the keyboard trying to understand the controls, it quite quickly jumped to one of my top 10 games of all time. The recently announced Mirror's Edge 2 is definitely on my watch list.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the most unique games you'll ever  play, albeit not without it's rough edges. Mirror's Edge fuses platforming and parkour in a first-person perspective. You'll do lots of climbing and running, and with the exception of a few problem areas, it's very easy to control your character. The visual design is an eye-catching mix of real and abstract, with lots of sterile white and heavily-saturated colors that help you quickly make your way along rooftops and through interior sections.The sound design and music are excellent. Objects whizz by your ears and you feel every scrape, slide, and impact. The music is dynamic, changing based on whether or not you are being pursued or what you're doing.That said, Mirror's Edge suffers from its own design. The level design is near-perfect at some times, but in other times the layouts are so damn confusing. Autosaves are well-placed, but it tends to rub salt in the would, especially considering how hard it is to make vertical distance as opposed to horizontal distance. The controls in the context of climbing or scaling things are either unresponsive or lead to unintended consequences.And to add to these occasional moments of frustration, the game boasts micro-sized gunfights and a few scripted fight sequences. These do a decent job of breaking the platforming, but they're frustrating in their own right. The gunplay feels very hollow and brings the speed and grace to a grinding halt. Normally you can run past your assailants, but a few times you will need to disarm them and slaughter every hostile in the area before you can continue. It feels incredibly shoehorned, half-baked, and I daresay it goes against the setting and the characters' nature. There are also two or three sequences where you need to fight or disarm someone as part of a cutscene, and these are not only frustrating, but they stop the game flow entirely.There's also the issue of the story. It's all over the place, and it rarely makes sense. She's something of a courier, but her higher-up has no qualm about her running around and trying to solve her own problems instead of actually doing her job. The game shuffles you around different areas and stories, hoping you won't realize it actually fleshes none of them out. The animated cutscenes are nice, but considering the game can be completed in an afternoon, there's nothing long-lasting about them. It's the kind of game that would benefit from a nicely-crafted story; unfortunately, you won't get that here.Despite all this, however, Mirror's Edge isn't a bad game. It shows hints of pure genius, and for the most part it's good. It's unique enough to stand out in almost every aspect, but the experience as a whole is kind of forgettable.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												In Mirror's Edge, you can choose to either play aggressively or passively. The whole fun of the game (and the obvious core) is running around and doing parkour in possibly one of the most beautiful cities you could ever parkour in (and clean). For a game released in 2009, it's more than what you could ask for (visually/aesthetically talking). The clean, peaceful and safe feeling that the environment around you provides is simply amazing (which is funny seeing how sometimes you might be running for your life). Even though the overall game is visually stunning, some of the levels (again, visually speaking) will just keep you speechless (causing my deaths several times in several levels, but..."IT WAS TOTALLY WORTH IT."The game itself, well. Some levels you will find incredibly frustrating and nearly impossible at times, but that's actually a good thing, or a pro about the game. The reason behind this is, because once you manage to accomplish the level, the satisfaction and the sense of accomplishment (and lets admit, cleverness) is beyond satisfying. Cons? Well, my top recommendation is to disable physx. That is basically the killer of the game. It can cause severe (and I mean SEVERE) frame issues and lag, even going as far as crashing your game. I'd also recommend avoiding confrontation when faced against many cops or snipers (oh how I despise those snipers).Oh and, you'll find out what I mean when I say that you should probably RUN FOR YOUR LIFE when you're being chased by your shadows (or runner's shadows, not quite a spoiler. As you probably don't have a clue of what I'm taking about).If you're having problems in deciding if the game is worth it or not, I guarantee it, if you love parkour and stunning visuals, go for it. I'd also recommend it so you get to know the origin of Mirror's Edge (as the second one will be coming out eventually).What are you waiting for, buy the game!

Posted: February 14, 2016
												Oh my god. I love this game and I hate it. The structure is sections of really, really satisfying first-person parkour broken up by awful sections where you'll die to a bunch of dudes with guns over and over. I don't know if I've ever played a game with such a huge gap between my best and worst experiences: at its best, its levels are designed like puzzles you need to solve with the handful of techniques you're taught (for better or worse) at the start of the game. At its worst, you're thrown into a big room with a bunch of boxes and heavily-armed guys, and given no sense of where to go or whether to fight. (Pressing the Alt key is supposed to direct your view toward your goal, but that's not always the case.)The joy of running, the visual design, and the world-building are all good enough, in my opinion, to still make this a game worth playing. I just wish I could give an unqualified recommendation.

												I've heard about ME years ago. After finishing the whole story line, I have to say that this is quite a great game, in my own opinion.As a parkour game, ME is totally focused on the element of PARKOURing. Unlike Assassin's Creed, which has a far longer story line, ME is totally about parkouring. The heroine, also known as Faith, runs around on the roofs and inside buildings in order to rescue her sister. Although the story line seems a little short for me, it is still a good game to play.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												Mirror's Edge. Painfully tedious at times, too heavily reliant on guns, unimpressive combat.And yet, the best parkour game out there, probably. (Until ME: Catalyst comes out.)Worth buying if you like these kinds of games.Parkour was not a theme commonly used in games until recently. So when Mirror's Edge came out no doubt people would have been excited. And as a person that enjoys Titanfall, I think it's got the best first-person mobility on the market. (ME, not Titanfall, great game though it is.)But the fluidity came at a cost. I can't help but feel DICE tried too hard to make it part-FPS. The combat breaks the smooth free feel of the game, unless you just run away. They're fixing this in Catalyst, making the combat more parkour-based, which is only good news. So, that's another box ticked for fans of the game.One of ME's best qualities was that, in theory, most chapters could be beaten in one fluid run, without stopping. And it does a good job of replicating the adrenaline-filled leaps of faith that comes with rooftop running.And you can't help but admire the art style of the city. It's a beautiful landscape of white and red that can hardly be put into words. It has to be experienced.Except that you're kind of trapped in small areas in the levels. But, again, DICE is adressing this and giving Catalyst the open world that the original desperately needed.To summmarise:Good parkourBad mostly everything else, but that doesn't matterEasy on the eyes - very easyNeeds open world and better fighting (both happening, thanks DICE)Buy this if you can't be bothered to climb a building and jump off roofs yourself.I would have made this review humourous, but I just couldn't think of any jokes. Sorry, folks.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												One of my all-time favourite platformers.  Ignore the lowish playtime; I've sunk hundreds of hours into this on different versions.  The common gripe, that combat breaks the freeflow of the running, is a legitimate one, but even the combat can be freeflowing on the hardest difficulty, with enough practise.  Unfortunately, despite my extreme love affair with Mirror's Edge, it is quite linear in nature (though there are a few alternate routes and tricks to speed your runs up), and there are only so many times you can play through the campaign.  The time trial runs offer plenty of replayability, though.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												This is my new favorite power-fantasy game.  It's not an objectively good game, but just from personal taste, I love it.  It really goes all-out with the first person view, most immersive I've seen without a VR headset.  I've always wanted a game where I can walljump or roll in first person, and now I have it!  Faith's acrobatics *feel* more powerful than pretty much any shoot-em-up or stab-em-up, it's simultaneously lower-power and way more superpowered than anything you can pull off in Skyrim.  The fight sequences aren't too exciting, but it's a really nice change to disarm enemies with good timing (and then throw away the gun because seriously who needs guns) instead of blowing them away.  Of course you don't have to throw away those guns, I'm sure my playthrough would have been a lot easier if I wasn't playing pacifist, but it felt more natural that way.  Weird.It's your standard Prince of Persia jumping-puzzle fare, which means there's spots that can be really frustrating to get through, but that only caught me a couple times.  Checkpoints are pretty liberal, so getting stuck is always "Getting past this part is hard", not "great, I need to backtrack through half the level again".Other comments...well, it's always nice having games with female protagonists and no romantic subplots.  The game feels a little short, but it was worthwhile, it didn't feel tedious.  There's hidden collectables (like pretty much every Prince of Persia style game) but there's not a whole lot; completionists won't lose whole weeks of their life over it, thank God.  It doesn't have achievements, which is really annoying considering that the console versions did get them.  Despite the fact that it's a console port though, the controls still feel simple and natural.  Fascinating bold use of colors in the game, I liked it a lot aesthetically.So, yeah.  In summary, it has cool aesthetics, and it makes you feel like a superhero more than any superhero game.  Very worthwhile diversion that won't eat up a lot of time.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												I enjoyed the time I had with Mirrors Edge. While it manages to pull of a beautifully fluent free running and combat system that tie greatly into the world, it does have its host of problems.The first thing I saw in Mirror's Edge was the controls. At first, I was hard on the idea that these controls sucked, and that they needed alot of tweaking. However, I learned quickly the game had a curve to it, and got passed the controls. When I finally got good at basic movements, I became absorbed in the world. The towering skyscrapers, colorful rooftops as well as the very dark secrets that were hid in this utopian masquerade. Cool right? Yes. However, it is really hard for me to appreciate the mythos of the game beyond its scenery, and beautiful scoring. This was because the story was god awful. Riddled with messy , sloppy, cheezy, and otherwise worthless dialouge, there was no way I was going to give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the sister to sister relationship in the story. And to put the icing on the cake, I was utterly displeased with the ending. You will know when you get there. Completely disregarding the story, the freerunning in the game was spectacular. With many ways to run on rooftops and build up momentum, I was very much envigorated when I pulled off the perfect string of moves. The blur on the sides of the screen when momentum building is a very amazing feeling. Then came the combat. For reasons I can not understand, people hated the combat in the game. And I agree and disagree at the same time. While pulling off ninja moves on a guard was fitting for the missons, the gunplay was stale. This could have easily been avoided by making weapons more sleek and getting rid of the heavy guns. It really brought me out of all the agility in the game when I lugging around a huge♥♥♥♥♥M249. So for Mirrors Edge 2, please keep the gunplay; but make it exciting! Make me feel like a badass when I finally get the gun out of the guards hands and run away from the firefight.There is also one other problem in the game, and that was the Runner's Vision. While artisticly this was cool, I felt as a game mechanic I did not like this. However, this really comes down to personal preference. I personally thought Runner's Vision held my hand throughout the game, highlighting where I should go next. Being chased from rooftop to rooftop by guards is not very fun when you know exactly where to go - I want to have to think fast to move to my objective! This mechanic can only be turned off on the hardest difficulty too, which is a shame. However, this is totally up to you on what you want out of Mirror's Edge. To conclude, Mirrors Edge is a great game. Free running is a wonderful time, and stringing together the perfect combo is simply rewarding as hell. The combat, while it can be vastly improved, is a good concept. And Runner's Vision is totally up to personal prefrence. The world is spectacular too, really putting a "POW" into the scenery with all its spectacular and vibrant color, while appropiatley contrasting the darkness that lies within the utopian universe. I really wish I could care more for the politics in this game, but the story is just too boring and dull for me to care! Characters are generic and unexciting, not to mention the cutscenes look like an All State commercial. But overall, this game is a gem, and the parkour is hands down the best I have ever been able to experience.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												tl;dr: Absolutely stunning and vibrant visuals, a masterfully performed soundtrack, unique, heart-pumping gameplay that tests your spatial awareness skills and encourages you to run the levels as smoothly as possible, and a lifelike world. It is a bit short however (my playthrough took 4 hours). All in all, Mirror's Edge is most definitely worth your money. Buy it now.Mirror's Edge, developed by DICE (makers of the Battlefield series), released in 2008, is a first person running game. You play as Faith Connors, a Runner in a futuristic unnamed city in which the government monitors all forms of communication. Runners were established to send messages without the government knowing about it. The plot revolves around Faith's sister being framed for a murder she didn't commit, and Faith unraveling the web of truth, forgive my simplistic metaphor. There are 9 chapters in the game, each one separated by an animated cutscene. Mirror's Edge, however, is not praised for it's intricate story. The component that shines is the unique gameplay. Despite being developed by the makers of the Battlefield series, combat is far from the focus of this game. The main objective is to traverse from point A to point B via rooftops, air vents, hallways, whatever stands in Faith's way. All of this is done on foot. Occasionally, the police force (referred to as "Blues" by the characters) show up to try and kill Faith. The Blues are dangerous, and should not be confronted head-on. The main strategy of survival is avoiding enemies and escaping them. Faith is not a fighter, she's a runner. Her only weapons are the environment around her and her limbs. A neat mechanic that greatly enhances the experience of Mirror's Edge is "Runner Vision". What this does is highlight possible pathways through the level, making it easy for the player to focus on the immersive world and parkour experience. Certain objects such as ramps, ziplines, and doors are highlighted to guide the player along. If the player is stuck and does not know where to go, pressing a key (or B on an Xbox 360 controller) will snap the camera to the direction of the objective. While Mirror's Edge is a fantastic experience, it is lacking in the length department. I completed the main story in under 5 hours, and that was with countless deaths and moments of "What the hell am I supposed to do here?". The game makes up for it by including a separate "speed run" mode for each level, and additional time trials. Overall, Mirror's Edge is a fulfilling and satisfying experience that delivers on all levels. The visuals are vibrant and memorable, the soundtrack adds the perfect amounts of ambience and tension, the plot is interesting enough, and the gameplay keeps you coming back for more. I highly recommend playing this at least once in your gaming career.

												8/10: Mirror's Edge is a very cool game. I thought I'd better try it out since Mirror's Edge 2 will be coming out, and I'm sure glad I did. Mirror's Edge offers a really unique and entertaining form of gameplay with its free-running mechanics and a beautiful world with vibrant colors to enjoy them in. The story isn't amazing, but it works well with the gameplay. The gunplay/combat is pretty poor (though you can pull off a pretty sweet dropkick), and I wish you had the option of simply avoiding fighting altogether, so you could focus on the aspect of the game that really shines: its core mechanics. Running, jumping, and navigating the city feels extremely satisfying, and the game presents you with many exciting environments to test your parkour skills. The chase scenes in particular can be quite exhilarating. There are some moments of frustration and minor annoying details, but overall the free-running system is done very well. There is also definitely some good replay value as there are time trials, and the main story could easily be enjoyed for multiple playthroughs. I will definitely be looking forward to the sequel.

												Mirror's Edge. Fast-paced action game all about momentum and using three buttons to do a million things. The game is set in a dystopian and overly uniform city of towering skyscrapers, and the plot revolves around the murder of a close friend of the main character's family. The game is essentially get to Point A to Point B, without dying, as fast as you can. Combat is rather awkward and there isn't much of a way to learn moves except trial and error, which can prove to be extremely irratating. Graphics reflect the dystopian world in solid, vivid colors, and keep the puzzles simpler as different key objects can be easily separated by the distinct colors. Voice acting is tolerable, but not especially impressive. As previously mentioned, momentum is imperative in performinfg many of the game's not-so-realistic moves, but oddly is often lost in solving some of the intermediately difficult puzzles. Overall, I would recommend this game.Graphics: simple yet uniquely beautiful. Gameplay: engaging, smooth and straightforward, although some moves are difficult to figure out. Story: not exactly gripping, but good enough for a parkour game.I would give it a confident 8/10 review.

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a first person parkour game with platforming and shooter elements. The player takes control of Faith as she uncovers the plot of murder, into which her sister was framed.The graphics look amazing for its time, and stand out even today. Just like it's name suggests, the environments are shiny and often pure eye candy (if you like big cities or semi-futuristic rooms).The gameplay is very simple: you use your parkour skills to move from one location to the next, exploring new areas, forwarding the story, and sometimes fighting enemies. For movement, you can perform wallruns, walljumps, pull-ups, rolls, slides... overall, it feels like there is no obstacle you can't surmount. The game (on lower difficulties, at least) also supplies you with Runner Vision, coloring red every object that you can use to move forward. The controls, while not lacking in options, do feel kind of stiff however. Mostly because you see everything from first-person perspective and thus your vision is often obscured by some objects. Environmental awareness is the key to success. Also, one bad jump or trick can send you plummetting to your death (which is a quite realistic portrayal of how it feels to fall from 30-story building to your death), but whenever that happens, it's almost always your fault.Combat, however, tends to be frustrating. Considering a few bullets will put you down and you often fight several gun-wielders while unarmed, it's quite understandable that you'll be at a disadvantage. Even on Normal it's very easy to lose. However, it's not that bad once you get the hang of it and can also wield weapons taken from defeated enemies (you do only get one clip, tho). The game gives you pistols, submachine guns, machine guns, and even sniper rifles at some points of the game, so don't be afraid to use those.The game offers three main gamemodes: Story, Race and Speedrun. Story allows you to play through different chapters of the story mode, accompanied by comic book-style custscenes. This mode is however very short, taking only maybe five hours to complete, including retries due to frequent deaths. Race allows you to do time trials on various short sections of the game, after which the game rates your performance. Speedrun is unlocked after completing the game and is basically Race applied to whole chapters of the Story mode.Overall, this game is very well done, a bit short, but has a good replay value.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the most unique games you'll ever  play, albeit not without it's rough edges. Mirror's Edge fuses platforming and parkour in a first-person perspective. You'll do lots of climbing and running, and with the exception of a few problem areas, it's very easy to control your character. The visual design is an eye-catching mix of real and abstract, with lots of sterile white and heavily-saturated colors that help you quickly make your way along rooftops and through interior sections.The sound design and music are excellent. Objects whizz by your ears and you feel every scrape, slide, and impact. The music is dynamic, changing based on whether or not you are being pursued or what you're doing.That said, Mirror's Edge suffers from its own design. The level design is near-perfect at some times, but in other times the layouts are so damn confusing. Autosaves are well-placed, but it tends to rub salt in the would, especially considering how hard it is to make vertical distance as opposed to horizontal distance. The controls in the context of climbing or scaling things are either unresponsive or lead to unintended consequences.And to add to these occasional moments of frustration, the game boasts micro-sized gunfights and a few scripted fight sequences. These do a decent job of breaking the platforming, but they're frustrating in their own right. The gunplay feels very hollow and brings the speed and grace to a grinding halt. Normally you can run past your assailants, but a few times you will need to disarm them and slaughter every hostile in the area before you can continue. It feels incredibly shoehorned, half-baked, and I daresay it goes against the setting and the characters' nature. There are also two or three sequences where you need to fight or disarm someone as part of a cutscene, and these are not only frustrating, but they stop the game flow entirely.There's also the issue of the story. It's all over the place, and it rarely makes sense. She's something of a courier, but her higher-up has no qualm about her running around and trying to solve her own problems instead of actually doing her job. The game shuffles you around different areas and stories, hoping you won't realize it actually fleshes none of them out. The animated cutscenes are nice, but considering the game can be completed in an afternoon, there's nothing long-lasting about them. It's the kind of game that would benefit from a nicely-crafted story; unfortunately, you won't get that here.Despite all this, however, Mirror's Edge isn't a bad game. It shows hints of pure genius, and for the most part it's good. It's unique enough to stand out in almost every aspect, but the experience as a whole is kind of forgettable.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												I dont do very many reviews, in fact I have to be truly impressed with a game or thoroughly dislike one to even bother.Mirrors Edge has landed on truly impressed. The citywide graphics are refreshingly bright and crisp, where most rpg graphics tend to be dark and sinister this brings a really nice feel of realism to the game. The only issue I had with framerate was when a lot of bullets are flying and cops are chasing Faith the impact of the particle system slowed them down a touch. My system can handle them but just to be sure I lowered the settings and lost very little of the detail and none of the beauty of the game and the framerate never wavered. The CG cutscenes are very well done and fall into the action with seamless ease. I personally would have liked to see more of these and a bit less of the cartoon styled ones, but thats just a matter of preference and takes nothing away from the story. The story thus far is well written and nicely voice acted, emersing you into the game and keeping you hungry to see what happens next. The combination of eyecandy graphics and great storyline are what has impressed me the most. I cant wait to see if they truly do make a Mirror's Edge movie and will absolutely want a copy. This brings me to gameplay, which takes some timing skill and plays out a lot like a 3D platform game might, with Faith running the rooftops for her life, jumping and sliding, in parkour style movements that have to be perfectly timed to keep her from falling to certain injury or death. Dont expect to fight your way out of most situations. Yes she has some skills but this isnt a female Rambo. She fights only when she has to. Which for myself only makes it seem more realistic and challenging. Albeit the story line is a bit linear the game does have a race mode and challenges that give it some replay value, and hours of story game play that will keep you coming back. Not many games can hold my attention enough to make me forget time. But it was easy for me to sit down here thinking I'll play for an hour and go to bed , only to look at the clock four hours later and wonder where the time went. Addictive, emersive gaming, I absolutely reccomend this to anyone looking for something new and exciting to play.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												A race for time, or a waste of time?Mirror's Edge takes something that many of us wish we were fit enough to do, and makes it into a core gameplay mechanic for anyone to enjoy. Is it fun? Yes! Absolutely! But it's not as groundbreaking as some hoped it would be (someone like me :P).It's a good game with some designer flaws, none of which, however, deter from the experience. Allow me to elaborate.In this game you play as a runner named Faith (how quaint) who runs into a, well, let's call it a "political disagreement" with the local PD, giving her (and you) an excuse jump off walls, off buildings, off TRAINS! Basically there is a lot of stuff to jump off of. And on, as well, as you are given the ability to beat the crap out of your enemies using said running and jumping abilities. This is very a smooth combat system, and very entertaining to do, as using your momentum to drive your punches and kicks like a projectile leaves you with an awesome feeling. The game seems to suffer from some kind of split personality disorder, though, as it can't tell if it wants to be a freerunning racing game, or another stylish EA shooter (meh). There are several points in the game where the only way to progress is to pick up a gun and blast/snipe your way through. Luckily there are only a few parts like these. The game markets itself as something unique and different that the current FPS generation would enjoy, however if you ignore running aspect and focus on what else the game is offering you basically have a linear campaign with several elements taken from games such as Half-Life 1+2 and portal, such as having to analyze your surroundings and cleverly use them to your advantage (another would be crawling through the air vents). This doesn't necessarily make this a bad game, just don't expect it to be ground breaking. I thought I was going to have an experience similar to Prince of Persia, but really it was far from it. It's a game of speed and momentum, where you are trying to get from point A to point B in the smoothest and quickest way possible, whereas Prince is about using special climbing techniques to solve puzzles that take up entire rooms.The graphics are great, and the massive city truely looks amazing. The Unreal 3 engine really shines in this game. I just wish we could actually go into the city and explore it more. Instead you are guided through a linear path, probably because that way it could tell the story, however unrelatable it was. It's clear that they worked hard on the story, but it's just so convoluted that I found myself paying less and less attention to it as I went along. The gameplay keeps you more engaged than the story, which is ok.I personally liked it, and found myself coming back to the time trials to kill some time. Without a doubt this game had much more potential, and with the fact that they had to revise the story several times, it kinda shows. But for a new IP with an experimental play style it seemed to present itself quite well. I would recommend this game to people who want to kill a weekend with some high velocity scissor kicks and clever outside-the-box speed run levels.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Mirror's Edge is an extremely enjoyable game that provides great freedom to the player in regards to speed.This game is a first person game where you are able to run as fast as you can to get to point A to point B. And it does not disappoint in doing so. You can climb over many obstacles, gaining momentum as you zip through your mission. Speed matters in this game, and Mirror's Edge does a good job at bringing parkouring to life. You can jump to buildings, climb on pipes, wall run across billboards, and sprint your way to the goal. There is so much you can do in regards to running and the adrenaline you get from it is amazing. There are not a lot of games out there that solely focus on freerunning (InMomentum and the Assassin's Creed series only come to mind to me) but this game harbors a great experience. The story is neat, and you can enjoy some time trials to beat your old times or top others. There are some puzzles in the game that you have to go through, but it's what makes the runner experience just as fun.There are some issues that I would like to point out. The story is short. I was disappointed when the game had ended to early, and would like it if they added more to the mix. The combat system could have been improved as well. In some instances in the game you would resort to killing your enemies via gun or hand-to-hand combat. Fighting in this game wasn't really satisfying, but it didn't ruin the experience for me. I had more fun sprinting freely through obstacles than punching guys who sometimes are not worth fighting.I hightly recommend this to those who love freerunning and a fast paced adventure game. Mirror's Edge brings up a nice take to a type of game that has not been touched upon in a while.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												7 out of 10.  I'm giving it a thumbs-up because the free-running gameplay is an interesting mechanic, but the game has enough faults that I really only recommend it when you can find it on sale.All in all not a very good game, even though it seems to have a pretty rabid fan base. To be fair, the graphics are very good, especially considering it's a few years old, and the developers had some innovative ideas for how to play the game. Unfortunately actually playing the game just wasn't as fun as it should have been. Mostly the game suffers from pretty bad controls coupled with unforgiving gameplay mechanics, which results in having to replay sections over and over again. Most jumps and grabs have to be precisely timed and the distance precisely judged, but many times the button presses didn't register quickly enough, and it's in general pretty difficult to judge distances, so I found myself dying dozens of times when I missed jumps by no more than an inch or two - that got frustrating really fast. The control issue also raised its ugly head in the wholly mediocre combat. Many, many times the right-mouse button counterattack failed, which got me killed more times than I could count. I eventually grew to hate the combat so much that I just pounded on the first guard I saw, took his gun, then shot everyone else just to get it over with.The other huge frustration with the game was the fact that for such a completely linear game it was often nearly impossible to figure out where to go. There was supposed to be a hint system that highlighted your path in red, but sometimes it showed up off in the distance, sometimes not until you were right on top of the path, and sometimes not at all - I wandered around a lot because of that. Even worse was the level where the devs decided to paint everything in the building red; I don't know why, I guess maybe they just thought it was funny to frustrate us even further.To make matters even worse (or perhaps better, as things turned out) - beyond the spotty controls, oft-failing hint system, unforgiving mechanics and mediocre combat, the game took me all of 5 hours and change to complete. I'm not necessarily opposed to short games, as long as the story is engaging and gameplay is fun - The Darkness II is a perfect example. But this game was neither engaging nor more than moderately fun, and was far too short for the money they normally charge. Luckily I got this as part of the EA Humble Bundle, so I really didn't shell anything out for it. If you can pick it up really cheap then it's fine to waste time on for a few hours, but anything more than a few bucks is probably a waste of your money.

Posted: December 22, 2012
												Mirror's Edge can be described in one word, and only one word really seems to fit. "Unique". Everything from the visual style of a bleached white city (which is hardly as boring to look at as it sounds) to the gameplay are some thing that I've never seen before, and am sad I haven't.The gameplay is hard to explain, and fits no real genre. "First person parkour shooter puzzle game" is probably the closest. When you reach that point in the game where you play flawlessly, able to launch over and under any obstacle you see it's something that feels... right.Combat is somewhat important, but most encounters can be avoided. Moving into combat comes as seamlessly as moving through parts of the level, and you can bring the same momentum and speed you feel in the parkour elements right into the battles.That's not to say the game is *all* gameplay. The story is also interesting, and the comic book style cutscenes do a great job portraying every important character in the game.It's not the world's longest game, but it's got immense replay value. Time trials, and the satisfaction of nailing each section with perfect landings and non stop running kept brining me back to the game.I recommend this game to fans of puzzle games (searching for paths to objectives up and down buildings and rooftops), and action game fans (because of the hectic movement and combat) alike. Every element seems to fall into place together, and it makes this a true classic that every fan of gaming should own a copy of.

												Parkour the Video Game. Though I'm kidding, that more or less describes this game. This game's gimmick is that you more or less traverse through its city/buildings with parkour-like moves. In the game you play as a courier/messenger that's outside of the law in a somewhat dystopian future. The story is fairly unoriginal, but if that doesn't bother you, then you'll greatly enjoy the game. The game is designed in such a way that you can get through each level/chapter in more ways than one. Besides choosing how to traipse from rooftop to rooftop, you're also able to determine how you go about dealing with combat. You can completely avoid it by running, hand to hand combat, or you can disarm your enemies and use their weapons against them. Some parts of the game will force you to deal with enemies in a specific manner, but for the most part, there's freedom to choose. Another thing to add, the game is fairly short. I played through around 66% of it in one sitting. The average play time is around 7 hours. There are ways to get at least 2 more hours of play time, but it would consist of scouring the levels for collectables. While that may seem fun for some, it's not really for me. Overall, I enjoyed the game, but it's not without its faults. I give this game a 3.5/5 and I recommend it.

Posted: September 17, 2014
												The selling point of 'Mirror's Edge' is the gameplay -- that is the parkour-inspired platforming in the first-person perspective. There was nothing like it at the time of the game's release, and there is nothing like it now at the time of this review. There is a story in 'Mirror's Edge', but it is not that interesting and is merely there to move the action along. As a fan of good stories in video games, I can overlook that because the first-person platforming is fun, albeit much, much trial and error is needed to complete a level most of the time.The game's clean, bright visuals are refreshing given the predominantly dark, brownish, shadowy looks of contemporary first-person shooters. The look of the game makes the gaming experience uplifting, which is much needed when you get frustrated from falling to your death many times in the game. There is an in-game system called "Runner Vision" that highlights environmental elements that are useful in solving the platforming puzzles, but those elements can still be hard to see as you may be in fast motion at the time. In later parts of the game, objects are highlighted less and less.The game is plagued with strange technical flaws that are hard to overlook though. First, if the PhysX option is turned on, it will cause debilitating drops in framerates if you are not using an nVidia GPU. (It should have been disabled automatically.) Second, you can't change a game's video settings mid-game and you will need to quit your current game to do so. Lastly, the checkpoints where you resume your game can vary, seemingly based on whether you are in the same game session (e.g. after an in-game death) or you are continuing a previously saved game (e.g. you start the game and click "Continue Game"). That means you may find yourself playing a level all over again just because you decided to quit the game mid-level. More frequent checkpoint saves would have been nice.At the time of this review, I have not played the game for over three months. I have uninstalled it even though I have not finished it because there is just not enough good points to lure me back for more. (Ironically in short, I have lost my momentum with the game.) Despite its flaws, I am still recommending 'Mirror's Edge', but not as enthusiastically as I had for games like 'Dishonored' and the 'Tomb Raider' reboot. There is much to improve on to make 'Mirror's Edge' an even better game, but what we have here is good enough to experience at a discount price.

Posted: October 19, 2015
												General impression:Mirror's Edge is a homage to parkour practice. The action takes place in an urban setting and wonderfully captures the atmosphere. It's a perfect game for speedrun and encourages players to push forward instead of taking out each and every enemy. Gameplay:The controls let you take full advantage of the environment and the feeling that you're doing parkour is ever present. However, once you've learned all the tricks, then that's all you'll have for the rest of the game. The moves became worn out after a while. It's a very simple game, you can do the wallrun and some other stuff and that's it: no character improvement, no inventory, no new skills. Fighting was introduced briefly but if felt cluncky. I always left it as the final option.Shooting felt like a really good idea but the game discouraged you to explore it. Using a controller is preferred over mouse and keyboard.Design:It looked and felt like Portal at times because of the design and also because of the environmental puzzles. I enjoyed the approach, it felt smart and beautiful. However, the lack of variety started to show itself by the time I was almost finished. Good thing that it was a short game.Characters:The protagonist Faith is a memorable and interesting character AND you'll see her a lot in cutscenes which help in building an emotional bond with her.The other characters were a letdown as were their agendas. I found myself wondering why some of them were necessary to build the story.Story:Most of the time it was hard to follow why some things were happening as they were. Then I re-read the plot after completing the game and understood that there was no story to follow. The motivating force that set the things in motion was a fuzzy mess. It were the loopholes in the story that made it hard to follow, not it's complexity.Verdict:I enjoyed playing this game but also got tired of it by the time I was through. There's a lot of room for improvement, the idea that it was too green for release spins in the back of my mind. If all those good ideas were polished and put into a sequel, I'd definitely show interest.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												Skip to bottom for key points.This game was straight up awesome.  Once you take the time to learn the controls and develop some rudimentary skills, the fun factor goes way up.  The most fun part of the game for me was the time trials, because it's just pure parkour all over the place.  You get to make the rooftops your own, and run/jump/climb all over your territory.  The campaign itself is quite good.  The writing isn't great, and the plot unfolds somewhat predictably, but that was never the main focus of the game.  The focus is running from the cops, or chasing other dudes, and that's where all the excitement is.  There is a ton of adrenaline value in most of the levels, and the non-chase puzzle levels are so interesting, you're still on the edge of your seat.  A lot of the enjoyment of the game comes from how good everything looks.  It's a bit unrealistic that everywhere you go is so clean and amazing looking, but that just adds to the experience, and helps to remove anything that might distract you while you run full speed past it all.  The only downside to the campaign is that once you've really hit your stride and parkour through the levels like lighting, it ends up being over rather quick, leaving you wanting more.  Then it's time to challenge yourself and run it all again, looking for quicker runs, and more efficient paths.  There's such a good selection of path options, that it really encourages you to make split second decisions, and judgement calls.  If you do get hung up, and decide to fight it out with the pursuers, there's a pretty interesting and engaging combat system.  *Spoilers*  The cops constantly try to kill you and never hesitate to open fire.  Shooting them is fun, but you don't get much ammo so if you go exterminator mode like I did, you have to plan out your attacks and work your way from enemy to enemy one at a time.  Fighting one enemy is really fun.  Fighting two gives you about a 50% survival chance but it's still doable and still fun if you pull it off.  It's understandably not fun to get mowed down from 3 or 4 different directions if you just run into the fray, and that's what happens, so you have to stay tactical.  *More SPOILERS*  The ninja dudes at the end are hard as hell to beat, but they are killable, and I figured out to beat the sh** out of those mofos, but again it involves extreme tactics.  They, like you, regenerate unless hit a lot of times in quick succession.  Get 3 good hits on them in under 10 seconds and you knock them the heck out, but that's so hard to pull off it's easier to just run away and escape them.  Just to summarizePros:  Fun CampaignFun extra modesAwesome concepts and executionCool main characterLevels look coolParkour looks awesome and sounds awesome (the sound clips used are perfect)Can play like a speed demon or a vengeful punisherCons:Campaign is short if you speed demon the whole thingStory is probably the least developed part of the game.How much fun you have depends on how well you learn the system and timing.I spent a lot of time on the levels, finding shortcuts, killing everything, and exploring, so I got a lot out of the game.  It's unique and it draws you in.  Immersive yet light on a heavy gamer's pallete.  I'd even say, it's an almost perfect game.  5/5 stars.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												The most common words out of your mouth when playing a game probably shouldn't be "oh for ♥♥♥♥'s sake". And yet...Yeah you don't need me to tell you what every other bad review has told you over the years but so thought I when I got this in the sale. I should preface by saying I really wanted to enjoy it, I mean really really wanted too but by the end, I was mad enough having spend £3 on it I'd've probably been been spitting if I spent ten. The sheer number of times you'll imagine your environment is built for a certain action and instead it will end with you plummeting to the street below is unreal. Say what you will of Assassin's Creed, at least it only tends to throw you to your death if you take a flying leap. Mirror's Edge will fling you off a ledge like an infant sacrifice if you sneeze while pressing left. Part of this is cos its so linear; you must Do The Thing in a timely manner or you will be getting aquainted with the floor super-quick. My only hope for people who play the sequel is that by then the dev team has fully worked up the environment and you can just fanny about in a giant playground should you so wish. My wishlist also follows; you have a circle of vision greater than the 45 degrees of wall you are facing when hanging from it; your only options when hitting a bloke isn't a one-two punch before getting rammed in the teeth with the butt of a rifle.In fairness, the story's alright, bit short but not awful. Non-descript villains who haven't really done something awful  except be ordered to stop the murder suspect, but who I'm going to shoot in the face anayway etc. I'd imagine you get more story -and feel like less of an♥♥♥♥♥ if you bother finding the runner's cases, since over the whole 7 hours I was playing I only came across five (I eschewed actually looking for them in favour of ending the farce as quick a possible) and at number five got a random burst of history lesson/moral patter from Faith that gave me V for Vendetta flashbacks. But again I didn't walk that road. Faith herself? Bit of a cow. By that logic she and I should get on, but instead I felt slightly more justified about the numerous times I would purposely hurl her off buildings -usually after another Stupid Death(TM)- just to hear all her bones go crunch when she met the pavement. That doesn't reflect well on me however so moving on.Its pretty too, I'll give it that. Although don't play in a dark room cos otherwise it ramps up from pretty to retina searing, say goodbye to a few colour receptors, because they will be inevitably BURNED AWAY.So if you want first person parkour I'd wait for the sequel to see if they've ironed out what didn't work. I can also imagine a few years down the line, after turning the saturation down (like to a dog's level of colour appreciation) playing this on Oculus Rift, cos THAT would make FPP fun, even if it will leave me in a puddle of my own sick.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												Skip to bottom for key points.This game was straight up awesome.  Once you take the time to learn the controls and develop some rudimentary skills, the fun factor goes way up.  The most fun part of the game for me was the time trials, because it's just pure parkour all over the place.  You get to make the rooftops your own, and run/jump/climb all over your territory.  The campaign itself is quite good.  The writing isn't great, and the plot unfolds somewhat predictably, but that was never the main focus of the game.  The focus is running from the cops, or chasing other dudes, and that's where all the excitement is.  There is a ton of adrenaline value in most of the levels, and the non-chase puzzle levels are so interesting, you're still on the edge of your seat.  A lot of the enjoyment of the game comes from how good everything looks.  It's a bit unrealistic that everywhere you go is so clean and amazing looking, but that just adds to the experience, and helps to remove anything that might distract you while you run full speed past it all.  The only downside to the campaign is that once you've really hit your stride and parkour through the levels like lighting, it ends up being over rather quick, leaving you wanting more.  Then it's time to challenge yourself and run it all again, looking for quicker runs, and more efficient paths.  There's such a good selection of path options, that it really encourages you to make split second decisions, and judgement calls.  If you do get hung up, and decide to fight it out with the pursuers, there's a pretty interesting and engaging combat system.  *Spoilers*  The cops constantly try to kill you and never hesitate to open fire.  Shooting them is fun, but you don't get much ammo so if you go exterminator mode like I did, you have to plan out your attacks and work your way from enemy to enemy one at a time.  Fighting one enemy is really fun.  Fighting two gives you about a 50% survival chance but it's still doable and still fun if you pull it off.  It's understandably not fun to get mowed down from 3 or 4 different directions if you just run into the fray, and that's what happens, so you have to stay tactical.  *More SPOILERS*  The ninja dudes at the end are hard as hell to beat, but they are killable, and I figured out to beat the sh** out of those mofos, but again it involves extreme tactics.  They, like you, regenerate unless hit a lot of times in quick succession.  Get 3 good hits on them in under 10 seconds and you knock them the heck out, but that's so hard to pull off it's easier to just run away and escape them.  Just to summarizePros:  Fun CampaignFun extra modesAwesome concepts and executionCool main characterLevels look coolParkour looks awesome and sounds awesome (the sound clips used are perfect)Can play like a speed demon or a vengeful punisherCons:Campaign is short if you speed demon the whole thingStory is probably the least developed part of the game.How much fun you have depends on how well you learn the system and timing.I spent a lot of time on the levels, finding shortcuts, killing everything, and exploring, so I got a lot out of the game.  It's unique and it draws you in.  Immersive yet light on a heavy gamer's pallete.  I'd even say, it's an almost perfect game.  5/5 stars.

												Mirrors Edge is one of my favourite games (I used to own it on Xbox and recently bought it on Steam) as it has a pretty good story, great atmosphere, amazing fluidity and action. The game is quite short but does offer a reasonable amount of replayability and has extra things to do such as challenges and time trials so its definitely worth buying especially in a sale. Overall I really enjoy this game and the only limitations/problems that i believe exist in this game are the lack of music whilst playing although this might detract from the action if it was present but also the play time. The play time is an issue because the main story can easily be done in about 4/5 hours as I found upon rebuying and playing this game as i managed to beat it in just about 3 hours but the normal new player might expect to beat it in 4/5. Althought despite this being a flaw I think I have collectively (On Xbox and PC) played through the story about 5 times (I think) and have spent numerous hours trying to beat personal bests in time trials and challenges so for me this hasn't been a massive problem but just thought it was the main and probably only limitation for Mirrors Edge on the whole. Have fun.EDIT: One thing I did forget to mention was that the only real difference from the console version to the PC version that makes the pc version a bit less enjoyable is the exclusion of achievements from PC as some of the achievements were extremely challenging and a good thing to show off your ability at a difficult game. For example some of the ones i remember were completing the game without shooting someone and another for not hitting people i think.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												The most common words out of your mouth when playing a game probably shouldn't be "oh for ♥♥♥♥'s sake". And yet...Yeah you don't need me to tell you what every other bad review has told you over the years but so thought I when I got this in the sale. I should preface by saying I really wanted to enjoy it, I mean really really wanted too but by the end, I was mad enough having spend £3 on it I'd've probably been been spitting if I spent ten. The sheer number of times you'll imagine your environment is built for a certain action and instead it will end with you plummeting to the street below is unreal. Say what you will of Assassin's Creed, at least it only tends to throw you to your death if you take a flying leap. Mirror's Edge will fling you off a ledge like an infant sacrifice if you sneeze while pressing left. Part of this is cos its so linear; you must Do The Thing in a timely manner or you will be getting aquainted with the floor super-quick. My only hope for people who play the sequel is that by then the dev team has fully worked up the environment and you can just fanny about in a giant playground should you so wish. My wishlist also follows; you have a circle of vision greater than the 45 degrees of wall you are facing when hanging from it; your only options when hitting a bloke isn't a one-two punch before getting rammed in the teeth with the butt of a rifle.In fairness, the story's alright, bit short but not awful. Non-descript villains who haven't really done something awful  except be ordered to stop the murder suspect, but who I'm going to shoot in the face anayway etc. I'd imagine you get more story -and feel like less of an♥♥♥♥♥ if you bother finding the runner's cases, since over the whole 7 hours I was playing I only came across five (I eschewed actually looking for them in favour of ending the farce as quick a possible) and at number five got a random burst of history lesson/moral patter from Faith that gave me V for Vendetta flashbacks. But again I didn't walk that road. Faith herself? Bit of a cow. By that logic she and I should get on, but instead I felt slightly more justified about the numerous times I would purposely hurl her off buildings -usually after another Stupid Death(TM)- just to hear all her bones go crunch when she met the pavement. That doesn't reflect well on me however so moving on.Its pretty too, I'll give it that. Although don't play in a dark room cos otherwise it ramps up from pretty to retina searing, say goodbye to a few colour receptors, because they will be inevitably BURNED AWAY.So if you want first person parkour I'd wait for the sequel to see if they've ironed out what didn't work. I can also imagine a few years down the line, after turning the saturation down (like to a dog's level of colour appreciation) playing this on Oculus Rift, cos THAT would make FPP fun, even if it will leave me in a puddle of my own sick.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a totally worth it game. Its now a little old (and as of the writing of this its been a while since ive played it) but its one of those games that I keep coming back to because its legit fun. This might be the first real Parkour game (don't honestly know of any before it) and in fact I didn't know Parkour was a real thing before this. Oh and did I mention its First Person? That's right, a first person shooter that basically doesn't have guns and you run from people instead of fighting them. Pretty cool right?So whats so great about this over looked diamond in the rough parkour game? Basically its all about fun. The environments are fun, its fun to navigate and fun to play. Ive played through it several times (its only like a couple hour length game) and have enjoyed it. Its not maybe the most polished and can sometimes be obvious that it isnt perfect but its enjoyable. If you like the genre or have never played a game of the genre you should pick this up. Its a run from the cops don't fight them mentality gameplay so the sense of urgency while you are being shot at is pretty fun. Jumping from roof to roof is pretty unique as well. The vertigo and the adrenaline are captured pretty well and Faith (the main character) is a really cool character despite not having enough game to get really fleshed out fully. Hopefully one day it will get a sequel. We can all hope.

Posted: April 18, 2014
Short Version+ great art design+ parcour running feels fantastic- highly frustrating fights- here and there problems with controls not reacting as expectedGame supports 360 controller and I recommend using it.Long VersionThis game could be awesome. But it has two serious problems. Let's start with the really great sides of Mirror's Edge. The art design is just astonishing. The looks of the city with their different color themes, the asia touch and the fitting music create an interesting futuristic scenario. These components established the same feeling which I had in Deus Ex: HR before. If you played it you will know what I mean. Also the parcour running is just pure fun. When you are able to chain multiple moves in a fast run you feel SO good! If the game would feature parcour runs only, it would probably one of my favourite games of all time. BUT the game also is higly frustrating. There are several sequences where you have to fight armed policemen. And it is possibly the most horrible thing I have ever experienced. You will die. You will die so often. And that is not all, it will also feel unfair. You know this feeling when you think you are doing the best the game has to offer and you still die almost randomly? At one point I even thought about quitting completely. Another con is that the controls are sometimes not precise. If you played the old Tomb Raider games you will remember deaths because you jumped 5 degrees in the wrong direction. Overall the controls are good, don't get me wrong, but I had several moments where I definitely pressed the right button in the right moment and still somehow fell down or the character didn't grab the ledge.Nevertheless if you are interested in the game you should grab it for this price. The good sides of it are worth experiencing the frustrating ones. In reflection I feel positive about Mirror's Edge. And from my personal point of view everyone who is interested in video games in general should know this title.You should also use a 360 Controller, the game even supports it.
